metadata.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose

facts.text: First respondent purchased the entire Touzi No. 341 of the 24-Parganas Collectorate at a revenue sale held on January 9, 1942.

As purchaser, first respondent acquired under section 37 of the Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859 the right to avoid and annul all under-tenures and forthwith to eject all under-tenants with certain exceptions.
In exercise of that right, respondent gave notices of ejectment and brought a suit in 1946 to evict certain under-tenants, including the second respondent, and to recover possession of the lands.
Suit decreed against second respondent who preferred an appeal to the District Judge, 24-Parganas, contending his undertenure came within one of the exceptions in section 37.
While appeal pending, West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 introduced on March 23, 1950, passed and came into force on March 15, 1950.
Amending Act substituted new section 37 enlarging exceptions, and section 7 provided that all pending suits, appeals and proceedings not resulting in delivery of possession shall abate.
Statement of objects and reasons: great hardship caused by section 37 in urban areas like Calcutta due to increase in land values leading to speculative purchases for large-scale eviction.
Respondent contended section 7 void as abridging fundamental rights under article 19(1)(f) and 31, moved High Court under article 228 to withdraw pending appeal.
High Court (Harries C.J. and Banerjee J.) by judgment dated March 22, 1951 declared section 7 unconstitutional and void, returned case to District Court.
High Court held respondent's vested right to annul under-tenures acquired before amendment, retrospective deprivation without abatement of price infringes article 19(1)(f), not saved by clause (5).
Subordinate Judge decreed suit on February 14, 1949; appeal filed March 25, 1949 as Title Appeal No. 252 of 1949.
High Court Reference No. 4 of 1950 in Civil Rule No. 1643 of 1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 is unconstitutional as violating article 19(1)(f) read with clause (5) by imposing unreasonable restriction on right to hold property.
Whether section 7 violates article 31(1) or (2) by depriving the respondent of property without authority of law or compensation.
Scope of article 19(1)(f) vs article 31: whether article 19(1)(f) protects concrete rights to specific property or general freedom to acquire, hold and dispose of property.

petitioner_arguments.text: If right to annul under-tenures is property under article 19(1)(f), it is also property under article 31(1), deprived by authority of law (section 7), hence lawful.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 31(1); Chiranjit Lal Chowdhury's case; Gopalan's case

petitioner_arguments.text: Nullification is reasonable restriction on enjoyment of property in interests of general public, considering hardships from section 37 in urban areas.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 19(1)(f) and (5); Statement of Objects and Reasons

respondent_arguments.text: Vested right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants acquired under purchase before amendment; retrospective deprivation without abatement of price infringes right to hold property under article 19(1)(f), not reasonable restriction.
Right conferred by old section 37 is itself property taken away without compensation violating article 31(2).

court_reasoning.text: Article 19(1)(f) declares general freedom/capacity of citizen to acquire, hold (own) and dispose of property, not concrete rights to specific property which is protected under article 31.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between natural rights in article 19 and concrete property rights in article 31; sub-clause (f) analogous to UN Declaration article 17.

court_reasoning.text: Article 31(1) requires deprivation only by authority of law (protection against executive); clause (2) elaborates for acquisition/taking possession requiring public purpose and compensation; clauses not mutually exclusive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deprivation under (1) is same as under (2); no police power conferred arbitrarily.

court_reasoning.text: Abridgement by new section 37 not substantial deprivation under article 31: enlarges exceptions but allows rent enhancement; in line with tenancy legislation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No withholding from possession/enjoyment, no serious impairment or material reduction in value.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in applying article 19(1)(f); restriction reasonable considering urban hardships, speculative evictions, ordinance urgency, pending cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statement of Objects, circumstances prevailing justify under article 19(5).

holdings.text: Article 19(1)(f) protects general right to acquire, hold and dispose of property, not specific vested rights which fall under article 31.
Section 7 does not effect deprivation of property under article 31 as abridgement not substantial.
Section 7 imposes reasonable restriction under article 19(5) even if applicable.

precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on article 31(1) and (2) by Das J., obiter, distinguished.
Analogy of reasoning; rejection of due process, no police power in Constitution.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. V.G. Row
Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd.
Butchers Union etc. Co. v. Crescent City etc. Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Privileges and immunities include right to hold and dispose of property as fundamental.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Land Revenue Sales Act, 1859
statutes_cited.relevance: Original section conferred right to annul under-tenures; substituted by amendment.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Land Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Substituted new s.37 enlarging exceptions; s.7 abates pending proceedings retrospectively.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights to property; challenged provisions violate Arts 19 and 31.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of High Court set aside declaring section 7 constitutional; case to proceed in lower court.
outcome.relief_granted: None specified beyond setting aside High Court judgment.
outcome.costs: First respondent to pay costs of appeal to appellant here and in lower court.

key_quotes.text: Sub-clause (f) of clause (1) of article 19 seems analogous to clause (1) of article 17 of the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights: 'Everyone has the right to own property alone as well as in association with others' and article 31 to clause (2) of article 17: 'No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his property.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes general freedom under Art 19 from specific protection under Art 31.

key_quotes.text: Broadly speaking it may be said that an abridgement would be so substantial as to amount to a deprivation within the meaning of article 31 if, in effect, it withheld the property from the possession and enjoyment of the owner, or seriously impaired its use and enjoyment by him, or materially reduced its value.
key_quotes.speaker: court
